In [[computing]], '''VMware View''' is a commercial [[desktop virtualization | desktop-virtualization]] product developed by [[VMware|VMware, Inc]]. Its first two releases (2.0.0 and 2.1.0) sold under the name '''VMware VDM''', but with the 3.0.0 release in 2008<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.vmware.com/company/news/releases/vmware_view_3.html | title = VMware Announces General Availability of VMware View 3, with Ground-Breaking Advances in Managing, Scaling and Personalizing Virtual Desktop Environments | date = 2008-12-02 | work = VMware News Release | publisher = VMware | location = Palo Alto | accessdate = 2010-08-12 | quote = PALO ALTO, Calif., December 2, 2008 â VMware Inc. [...] today announced the general availability of VMware View 3 [...] }} </ref> VMware Inc. changed the name to "VMware View".
'''VMware View''' provides remote desktop capabilities to users using VMware's virtualization technology. A client desktop operating system - typically Microsoft Windows 7, Vista or XP - are run within a virtual environment on a server. The VMware View product has a number of components which are required to provide the virtual desktops, including: * VMware vSphere for Desktops (includes ESX/ESXi virtualization) * VMware vCenter Server (management of virtualization environment) * View Composer (advanced View management, with automation and cloning) * View Manager (administration of the View Environment) * View Client(communication between view and the desktop OS)
In order to transport a view of the desktop to users, keyboard, video, mouse and other interactions are sent over a LAN connection. Protocols supported for this are both the Microsoft-developed RDP ([[Remote Desktop Protocol]]), along with the [[PCoIP]] protocol. Access is also supported through any HTML5 compliant browser.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://communities.vmware.com/thread/308262 | title = VMware Community }}</ref>
Client connections to VMware View sessions are established by running a VMware View Client on a local host. Clients are supported for most versions of Windows, along with Mac OS X. Specific embedded clients are also supported for a large number of thin clients, for a list of supported clients refer to the VMware website.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.vmware.com/resources/compatibility/search.php?deviceCategory=vdm | title = VMware View 4.5 HCL for thin devices }}</ref>
An [[open-source]] product called "VMware View Open Client" can connect from a Linux or Mac OS X desktop to remote Windows desktops managed by VMware View.<ref> [http://blogs.vmware.com/view/2009/02/vmware-view-open-client---now-available.html VMware: VMware View: VMware View Open Client - Now Available]</ref>
An [[HTML5]] Client for VMware View is available to enable access to VMware View desktops directly from within any [[HTML5]]-compatible web browser such as Safari, Chrome, IE and [[Firefox]] (for [[Windows]], Linux, Mac and [[Chrome OS]] devices, such as [[Chromebooks]]).<ref> {{cite web | url = http://communities.vmware.com/message/1726653 | title =VMware Community - HTML5 Client for VMware View }}</ref>
